mn149:0.2.eng: The Great Discourse on What Relates to the Six Sense Fields

mn149:1.1.comm: This discourse is “great” because it integrates multiple distinct teaching frameworks within the six sense fields. These include the majority of the saṁyutta-mātikā, the list of topics making up the Saṁyutta Nikāya.

mn149:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn149:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn149:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

mn149:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, I shall teach you the great discourse on what relates to the six sense fields.
mn149:2.1.comm: For āyatanika see MN 121:10.5, where it refers to the life faculty of the body that is “related to the six sense fields”; there are also heavens and hells “related to the six fields of contact” (MN 50:22.2, Sb 35:35.135). In each case it refers to something that is connected to or related to the six sense fields, as indicated by the suffix ika. Here this refers to the fact that this discourse treats multiple distinct teaching frameworks in relation to the six sense fields. These include the majority of the saṁyutta-mātikā, the list of topics making up the Saṁyutta Nikāya. And this inclusive and integrative nature in turn explains why the teaching is “great”.

mn149:2.2.pli: Taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
mn149:2.2.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

mn149:2.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

mn149:3.1.pli: “Cakkhuṃ, bhikkhave, ajānaṃ apassaṃ yathābhūtaṃ, rūpe ajānaṃ apassaṃ yathābhūtaṃ, cakkhuviññāṇaṃ ajānaṃ apassaṃ yathābhūtaṃ, cakkhusamphassaṃ ajānaṃ apassaṃ yathābhūtaṃ, yamidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi ajānaṃ apassaṃ yathābhūtaṃ, cakkhusmiṃ sārajjati, rūpesu sārajjati, cakkhuviññāṇe sārajjati, cakkhusamphasse sārajjati, yamidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tasmimpi sārajjati.
mn149:3.1.eng: “Mendicants, when you don’t truly know and see the eye, sights, eye consciousness, eye contact, and what is felt as pleasant, painful, or neutral that arises dependent on eye contact, you’re aroused by these things.

mn149:3.2.pli: Tassa sārattassa saṃyuttassa sammūḷhassa assādānupassino viharato āyatiṃ pañcupādānakkhandhā upacayaṃ gacchanti.
mn149:3.2.eng: Someone who lives aroused like this—fettered, confused, concentrating on gratification—accumulates the five grasping aggregates for themselves in the future.
mn149:3.2.comm: In other words, one who becomes attached to sense experience creates kamma that generates a new life consisting of the five aggregates. This passage integrates the teachings on the six sense fields and the five aggregates under the first noble truth, as well as briefly implying the basic principle of dependent origination.

mn149:3.3.pli: Taṇhā cassa ponobbhavikā nandīrāgasahagatā tatratatrābhinandinī, sā cassa pavaḍḍhati.
mn149:3.3.eng: And their craving—which leads to future lives, mixed up with relishing and greed, taking pleasure wherever it lands—grows.
mn149:3.3.comm: This is the second noble truth.

mn149:3.4.pli: Tassa kāyikāpi darathā pavaḍḍhanti, cetasikāpi darathā pavaḍḍhanti;

mn149:3.5.pli: kāyikāpi santāpā pavaḍḍhanti, cetasikāpi santāpā pavaḍḍhanti;

mn149:3.6.pli: kāyikāpi pariḷāhā pavaḍḍhanti, cetasikāpi pariḷāhā pavaḍḍhanti.

mn149:3.7.eng: And they experience physical and mental suffering.

mn149:4-7.1.eng: When you don’t truly know and see the ear …

mn149:4-7.5.pli: manaṃ, bhikkhave, ajānaṃ apassaṃ yathābhūtaṃ, dhamme, bhikkhave, ajānaṃ apassaṃ yathābhūtaṃ, manoviññāṇaṃ, bhikkhave, ajānaṃ apassaṃ yathābhūtaṃ, manosamphassaṃ, bhikkhave, ajānaṃ apassaṃ yathābhūtaṃ, yamidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi ajānaṃ apassaṃ yathābhūtaṃ, manasmiṃ sārajjati, dhammesu sārajjati, manoviññāṇe sārajjati, manosamphasse sārajjati, yamidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tasmimpi sārajjati.
mn149:4-7.5.eng: mind, ideas, mind consciousness, mind contact, and what is felt as pleasant, painful, or neutral that arises dependent on mind contact, you’re aroused by these things.

mn149:8.1.pli: Tassa sārattassa saṃyuttassa sammūḷhassa assādānupassino viharato āyatiṃ pañcupādānakkhandhā upacayaṃ gacchanti.
mn149:8.1.eng: Someone who lives aroused like this—fettered, confused, concentrating on gratification—accumulates the five grasping aggregates for themselves in the future.

mn149:8.2.pli: Taṇhā cassa ponobbhavikā nandīrāgasahagatā tatratatrābhinandinī, sā cassa pavaḍḍhati.
mn149:8.2.eng: And their craving—which leads to future lives, mixed up with relishing and greed, taking pleasure wherever it lands—grows.

mn149:8.3.pli: Tassa kāyikāpi darathā pavaḍḍhanti, cetasikāpi darathā pavaḍḍhanti;

mn149:8.4.pli: kāyikāpi santāpā pavaḍḍhanti, cetasikāpi santāpā pavaḍḍhanti;

mn149:8.5.pli: kāyikāpi pariḷāhā pavaḍḍhanti, cetasikāpi pariḷāhā pavaḍḍhanti.

mn149:8.6.eng: And they experience physical and mental suffering.

mn149:9.1.pli: Cakkhuñca kho, bhikkhave, jānaṃ passaṃ yathābhūtaṃ, rūpe jānaṃ passaṃ yathābhūtaṃ, cakkhuviññāṇaṃ jānaṃ passaṃ yathābhūtaṃ, cakkhusamphassaṃ jānaṃ passaṃ yathābhūtaṃ, yamidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi jānaṃ passaṃ yathābhūtaṃ, cakkhusmiṃ na sārajjati, rūpesu na sārajjati, cakkhuviññāṇe na sārajjati, cakkhusamphasse na sārajjati, yamidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tasmimpi na sārajjati.
mn149:9.1.eng: When you do truly know and see the eye, sights, eye consciousness, eye contact, and what is felt as pleasant, painful, or neutral that arises dependent on eye contact, you’re not aroused by these things.

mn149:9.2.pli: Tassa asārattassa asaṃyuttassa asammūḷhassa ādīnavānupassino viharato āyatiṃ pañcupādānakkhandhā apacayaṃ gacchanti.
mn149:9.2.eng: Someone who lives unaroused like this—unfettered, unconfused, concentrating on drawbacks—disperses the five grasping aggregates for themselves in the future.

mn149:9.3.pli: Taṇhā cassa ponobbhavikā nandīrāgasahagatā tatratatrābhinandinī, sā cassa pahīyati.
mn149:9.3.eng: And their craving—which leads to future lives, mixed up with relishing and greed, taking pleasure wherever it lands—is given up.

mn149:9.4.pli: Tassa kāyikāpi darathā pahīyanti, cetasikāpi darathā pahīyanti;

mn149:9.5.pli: kāyikāpi santāpā pahīyanti, cetasikāpi santāpā pahīyanti;

mn149:9.6.pli: kāyikāpi pariḷāhā pahīyanti, cetasikāpi pariḷāhā pahīyanti.

mn149:9.7.eng: And they experience physical and mental pleasure.

mn149:10.1.pli: Yā tathābhūtassa diṭṭhi sāssa hoti sammādiṭṭhi;
mn149:10.1.eng: The view of such a person is right view.

mn149:10.2.pli: yo tathābhūtassa saṅkappo svāssa hoti sammāsaṅkappo;

mn149:10.3.pli: yo tathābhūtassa vāyāmo svāssa hoti sammāvāyāmo;

mn149:10.4.pli: yā tathābhūtassa sati sāssa hoti sammāsati;

mn149:10.5.pli: yo tathābhūtassa samādhi svāssa hoti sammāsamādhi.
mn149:10.5.eng: and their immersion is right immersion.

mn149:10.6.pli: Pubbeva kho panassa kāyakammaṃ vacīkammaṃ ājīvo suparisuddho hoti.
mn149:10.6.eng: And their actions of body and speech, and their livelihood, have already been fully purified before.

mn149:10.7.pli: Evamassāyaṃ ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchati.
mn149:10.7.eng: So this noble eightfold path is fully developed.

mn149:10.8.pli: Tassa evaṃ imaṃ ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāvayato cattāropi satipaṭṭhānā bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchanti, cattāropi sammappadhānā bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchanti, cattāropi iddhipādā bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchanti, pañcapi indriyāni bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchanti, pañcapi balāni bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchanti, sattapi bojjhaṅgā bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchanti.
mn149:10.8.eng: When the noble eightfold path is developed, the following are fully developed: the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, the four right efforts, the four bases of psychic power, the five faculties, the five powers, and the seven awakening factors.
mn149:10.8.comm: The eightfold path is brought in as well, along with the other main teachings of the path.

mn149:10.9.eng: And these two qualities proceed in conjunction:

mn149:10.10.comm: Discussed in more detail at AN 4.170.

mn149:10.11.pli: So ye dhammā abhiññā pariññeyyā te dhamme abhiññā parijānāti.
mn149:10.11.eng: They completely understand by direct knowledge those things that should be completely understood by direct knowledge.
mn149:10.11.comm: This refers to the distinct functions to be exercised in relation to each of the four noble truths (SN 56.11:5.1).

mn149:10.12.pli: Ye dhammā abhiññā pahātabbā te dhamme abhiññā pajahati.
mn149:10.12.eng: They give up by direct knowledge those things that should be given up by direct knowledge.

mn149:10.13.pli: Ye dhammā abhiññā bhāvetabbā te dhamme abhiññā bhāveti.
mn149:10.13.eng: They develop by direct knowledge those things that should be developed by direct knowledge.

mn149:10.14.pli: Ye dhammā abhiññā sacchikātabbā te dhamme abhiññā sacchikaroti.
mn149:10.14.eng: They realize by direct knowledge those things that should be realized by direct knowledge.

mn149:11.1.pli: Katame ca, bhikkhave, dhammā abhiññā pariññeyyā?
mn149:11.1.eng: And what are the things that should be completely understood by direct knowledge?

mn149:11.2.eng: You should say: ‘The five grasping aggregates.’

mn149:11.3.eng: That is: form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

mn149:11.4.eng: These are the things that should be completely understood by direct knowledge.

mn149:11.5.pli: Katame ca, bhikkhave, dhammā abhiññā pahātabbā?
mn149:11.5.eng: And what are the things that should be given up by direct knowledge?

mn149:11.6.eng: Ignorance and craving for continued existence.

mn149:11.7.eng: These are the things that should be given up by direct knowledge.

mn149:11.8.pli: Katame ca, bhikkhave, dhammā abhiññā bhāvetabbā?
mn149:11.8.eng: And what are the things that should be developed by direct knowledge?

mn149:11.10.eng: These are the things that should be developed by direct knowledge.

mn149:11.11.pli: Katame ca, bhikkhave, dhammā abhiññā sacchikātabbā?
mn149:11.11.eng: And what are the things that should be realized by direct knowledge?

mn149:11.13.eng: These are the things that should be realized by direct knowledge.

mn149:12-18.1.eng: When you truly know and see the ear …

mn149:12-18.5.pli: manaṃ, bhikkhave, jānaṃ passaṃ yathābhūtaṃ, dhamme jānaṃ passaṃ yathābhūtaṃ, manoviññāṇaṃ jānaṃ passaṃ yathābhūtaṃ, manosamphassaṃ jānaṃ passaṃ yathābhūtaṃ, yamidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi jānaṃ passaṃ yathābhūtaṃ, manasmiṃ na sārajjati, dhammesu na sārajjati, manoviññāṇe na sārajjati, manosamphasse na sārajjati, yamidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tasmimpi na sārajjati.
mn149:12-18.5.eng: mind, ideas, mind consciousness, mind contact, and what is felt as pleasant, painful, or neutral that arises dependent on mind contact, you are not aroused by these things. …

mn149:19.1.pli: Tassa asārattassa asaṃyuttassa asammūḷhassa ādīnavānupassino viharato āyatiṃ pañcupādānakkhandhā apacayaṃ gacchanti.

mn149:19.2.pli: Taṇhā cassa ponobbhavikā nandīrāgasahagatā tatratatrābhinandinī, sā cassa pahīyati.

mn149:19.3.pli: Tassa kāyikāpi darathā pahīyanti, cetasikāpi darathā pahīyanti;

mn149:19.4.pli: kāyikāpi santāpā pahīyanti, cetasikāpi santāpā pahīyanti;

mn149:19.5.pli: kāyikāpi pariḷāhā pahīyanti, cetasikāpi pariḷāhā pahīyanti.

mn149:20.1.pli: Yā tathābhūtassa diṭṭhi sāssa hoti sammādiṭṭhi;

mn149:20.2.pli: yo tathābhūtassa saṅkappo svāssa hoti sammāsaṅkappo;

mn149:20.3.pli: yo tathābhūtassa vāyāmo svāssa hoti sammāvāyāmo;

mn149:20.4.pli: yā tathābhūtassa sati sāssa hoti sammāsati;

mn149:20.5.pli: yo tathābhūtassa samādhi svāssa hoti sammāsamādhi.

mn149:20.6.pli: Pubbeva kho panassa kāyakammaṃ vacīkammaṃ ājīvo suparisuddho hoti.

mn149:20.7.pli: Evamassāyaṃ ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchati.

mn149:21.1.pli: Tassa evaṃ imaṃ ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāvayato cattāropi satipaṭṭhānā bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchanti, cattāropi sammappadhānā bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchanti, cattāropi iddhipādā bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchanti, pañcapi indriyāni bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchanti, pañcapi balāni bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchanti, sattapi bojjhaṅgā bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchanti.

mn149:22.3.pli: So ye dhammā abhiññā pariññeyyā te dhamme abhiññā parijānāti.

mn149:22.4.pli: Ye dhammā abhiññā pahātabbā te dhamme abhiññā pajahati.

mn149:22.5.pli: Ye dhammā abhiññā bhāvetabbā te dhamme abhiññā bhāveti.

mn149:22.6.pli: Ye dhammā abhiññā sacchikātabbā te dhamme abhiññā sacchikaroti.

mn149:23.1.pli: Katame ca, bhikkhave, dhammā abhiññā pariññeyyā?

mn149:24.1.pli: Katame ca, bhikkhave, dhammā abhiññā pahātabbā?

mn149:25.1.pli: Katame ca, bhikkhave, dhammā abhiññā bhāvetabbā?

mn149:26.1.pli: Katame ca, bhikkhave, dhammā abhiññā sacchikātabbā?

mn149:26.3.eng: These are the things that should be realized by direct knowledge.”

mn149:26.4.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn149:26.5.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
mn149:26.5.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
